1.title: Stoxy
1.headline: Why Stoxy?Small
1.body: No dependencies and no need for build tools.

2.title: Stoxy
2.headline: Global state
2.body: Handle state across the whole application, with immediate response from components.

3.title: Stoxy
3.headline: Zero Configuration
3.body: With plug and play implementation, you're up and running in just a single line of code.

4.title: Stoxy
4.headline: Extensive tooling
4.body: Stoxy ships with framework agnostic components to use with the state management system to achieve optimal results with your Web Application.

5.title: Stoxy
5.headline: Extendability
5.body: Built with small and powerful functions, allowing you to extend the functionality with predicates and delegates.

6.title: Stoxy
6.headline: Offline-ready
6.body: Stoxy can utilize the IndexedDB for storage, allowing you to create offline-first experiences without the hassle.

7.title: Docs
7.headline: DocsMotivation

8.title: Docs
8.headline: Simplicity
8.body:
All of Stoxy's commands are 1-2 parameters long, and can be executed as "one-liners". 
They are however extremely extendable due to the nature of the state management system of Stoxy. Some of the Stoxy core
functions like update  and remove   even take delegates or predicates as a parameter to give the developer
more control over their state management.

9.title: Docs
9.headline: Ecosystem
9.body:
Stoxy ships with a small set of Web Components, which are framework agnostic components ready for use in any project. 
The components are built to as reactive pieces of an application, updating their contents accordin to state
change without the developer having to do any work.

11.title: Methods: Persist Key
11.headline: Methods: Persist Key
11.body:
Declare a state object to be persisted through pageloads. 
Stoxy utilized IndexedDB to persist state objects. There could be two reasons you would want to persist your state objects: 

Persisted state objects are peristed through page page reloads / sessions 
Persisted state objects can be removed from cache, and only fetched when needed

20.title: Getting started: Core functionality
20.headline: Reactivity
20.body:
On top of the reactivity provided by the Stoxy elements, the developer can also subscribe to the
state updates happening around their web application. 
The developer is able to set a callback function to be called with the new data set onto the state, as the
state updates. This allows for reactive programming patterns to be done by the developer even without using
Stoxy elements. 
import  { sub}  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

sub ( "shoppingcart" ,  ( )  =>  console . log ( "Shopping card updated" ) ) ;

23.title: Getting started: Installation
23.headline: Getting started: Installation
23.body:
Stoxy can be installed as single packages or as a collection of all Stoxy elements and the core. 
To install the whole Stoxy project in one go, you can do so with 
npm  install  @stoxy/stoxy
  

Alternatively the packages can be installed as standalone installations

30.title: Docs
30.headline: Use them how you want to
30.body:
The whole core set of Stoxy is built from smaller modules, which can be attached at will. 
This means that you can use Stoxy only for managing state, and then handle all the events through subscribers,
or you can go all in on Stoxy and deploy a whole application built with stoxy elements using barely any Javascript

32.title: Components: Stoxy Form
32.headline: Components: Stoxy Form
32.body:
Stoxy Form is a web component used for handling Stoxy state without
having to write any javascript. 
On submit, the form persists the form's data to state with the given key attribute. 
If the url attribute is set, the form creates a HTTP request before saving the data to state.

33.title: Components: Stoxy Form
33.headline: Attributes
33.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Either add  or set  dependeing on wanted to add to a colleciton in state, or deplace the state  url In some cases you might want to send the form data to the backend. For these situations you can declare the url property. If set, sends a fetch request to given url on submit.  method If url is set, specifies the HTTP method used for the request. Defaults to GET  requireok If url is set, specifies if the HTTP request is required to return a OK status before committing the object to state.

34.title: Components: Stoxy Form
34.headline: Usage

35.title: Components: Stoxy Form
35.headline: Sending the form data to a API on submit
35.body:
In some cases we might want to send the data from the form to a backend API while we save it to our state at the
same time. This can be done by utilizing the stoxy-form's url  attribute. 
import  '@stoxy/form' ; 
  
<stoxy-form
    key="todos"
    action="add"
    url="https://my-website.app/todoadd"
    method="POST"
    requireok
    @submit=${() => {
         this.shadowRoot.querySelector('input').value = '';
    }}
>
    < input 
        type = " text"  
        name = " task"  
        placeholder = " Add todo..."  
        autocomplete = " off"  
    />  
    < input  type = " submit"   value = " Submit"   />  
</ stoxy-form >  

  
In the above case, a POST request would be made to https://my-website.app/todoadd , with the body
{ task: "Your input" } . 
The requireok  attribute means that unless we get a OK response from the backend, we won't save the
data to state either.

37.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
37.headline: Components: Stoxy Repeat
37.body:
Stoxy Repeat is a web component used for iterating state content onto the web page. 
The repeat component is useful for situations where the state object is iterable
and is desired to be displayed as e.g. a list 

As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Repeat also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

51.title: Recipes: Persisting data
51.headline: Recipes: Persisting data
51.body:
Persisting data means that the state persists through page reloads and even
navigation outside of the page. 
There are plenty of situtations where you might want to persist data. One example
would be persisting API data that doesn't update often, or implementing a Stale-While-Revalidate 
state management system 
Persisting data to IndexedDB isn't on by default, and needs to be opted in on a per-key basis. 
After declaring the key with persistKey  all the state of that key is persisted into the IndexedDB. 
import  {  persistKey }  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

persistKey ( "shoppingcart" ,  "userhistory" ) ;

52.title: Recipes: Persisting data
52.headline: Memory management
52.body:
Persisting data onto the IndexedDB could also have a performance benefit. When persisting data, the Stoxy
system only keeps the latest 5 cache objects in memory cache, and let's the garbage collection handle older
state objects. 
This means that for an application using a large amount of state keys, it might be beneficial to persist the data
to enable the memory management benefits.

a.title: Docs
a.headline: Persistence
a.body:
Stoxy comes shipped with persistence out of the box. There are many cases in which it is beneficial to persist the state
data through page reloads and navigation. Wether it be stale-while-revalidate patterns, or just static information fetched
from the API. 
The Persistence in Stoxy is opt-in, meaning that you control exactly what information gets persisted.

1x.title: Getting started: Core functionality
1x.headline: Getting started: Core functionality
1x.body:
Stoxy is a dynamic state management system, which allows the developer to handle state across the whole
application without hassle. 
Stoxy utilizes the IndexedDB  to persist
data across page reloads and navigation. The usage of IDB also means that state persisted onto it is accessible
even when the user is offline.

1y.title: Getting started: Core functionality
1y.headline: Persistance

1z.title: Getting started: Core functionality
1z.headline: Updates
1z.body:
Stoxy elements are a perfect tool for creating reactive web experiences. When using Stoxy elements, the developer
doesn't need to worry about reacting to state changes. The elements handle their state and updates to said state
automatically, without any input from the developer. 
The updates are ran in a dynamic fashion, and only the content that has updated will be changed. 
With elements like Stoxy Repeat , the iterable stateobject are
compared to their old state, and sorted automatically to match the new order of the
state array. Only the items in the wrong order are moved around the DOM, and the ones that didn't change order
will be kept untouched.

2a.title: Recipes: Persisting data
2a.headline: Recipes: Persisting data
2a.body:
Persisting data means that the state persists through page reloads and even
navigation outside of the page. 
There are plenty of situtations where you might want to persist data. One example
would be persisting API data that doesn't update often, or implementing a Stale-While-Revalidate 
state management system 
Persisting data to IndexedDB isn't on by default, and needs to be opted in on a per-key basis. 
After declaring the key with persistKey  all the state of that key is persisted into the IndexedDB. 
import  {  persistKey }  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

persistKey ( "shoppingcart" ,  "userhistory" ) ;

2b.title: Recipes: Persisting data
2b.headline: Memory management
2b.body:
Persisting data onto the IndexedDB could also have a performance benefit. When persisting data, the Stoxy
system only keeps the latest 5 cache objects in memory cache, and let's the garbage collection handle older
state objects. 
This means that for an application using a large amount of state keys, it might be beneficial to persist the data
to enable the memory management benefits.

2w.title: Docs
2w.headline: DocsMotivation

2x.title: Docs
2x.headline: Simplicity
2x.body:
All of Stoxy's commands are 1-2 parameters long, and can be executed as "one-liners". 
They are however extremely extendable due to the nature of the state management system of Stoxy. Some of the Stoxy core
functions like update  and remove   even take delegates or predicates as a parameter to give the developer
more control over their state management.

2y.title: Docs
2y.headline: Ecosystem
2y.body:
Stoxy ships with a small set of Web Components, which are framework agnostic components ready for use in any project. 
The components are built to as reactive pieces of an application, updating their contents accordin to state
change without the developer having to do any work.

2z.title: Docs
2z.headline: Persistence
2z.body:
Stoxy comes shipped with persistence out of the box. There are many cases in which it is beneficial to persist the state
data through page reloads and navigation. Wether it be stale-while-revalidate patterns, or just static information fetched
from the API. 
The Persistence in Stoxy is opt-in, meaning that you control exactly what information gets persisted.

3a.title: Components: Stoxy String
3a.headline: Components: Stoxy String
3a.body:
Stoxy String is a web component used for situtations, where you want to
display a single state object in the DOM, for example the current item count. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy String also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side. 

As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy String also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

3c.title: Components: Stoxy String
3c.headline: Usage
3c.body:
import  '@stoxy/stoxy-string' ; 
  
< p >  < stoxy-string >  itemcount</ stoxy-string >  </ p >  
  
Say the state object of itemcount  was 5 at the moment, we would have our DOM as: 
< p >  < stoxy-string >  5</ stoxy-string >  </ p >  
  
        
          import '@rocket/launch/inline-notification/inline-notification.js';

4s.title: Getting started: Core functionality
4s.headline: Reactivity
4s.body:
On top of the reactivity provided by the Stoxy elements, the developer can also subscribe to the
state updates happening around their web application. 
The developer is able to set a callback function to be called with the new data set onto the state, as the
state updates. This allows for reactive programming patterns to be done by the developer even without using
Stoxy elements. 
import  { sub}  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

sub ( "shoppingcart" ,  ( )  =>  console . log ( "Shopping card updated" ) ) ;

5t.title: Components: Stoxy Form
5t.headline: Components: Stoxy Form
5t.body:
Stoxy Form is a web component used for handling Stoxy state without
having to write any javascript. 
On submit, the form persists the form's data to state with the given key attribute. 
If the url attribute is set, the form creates a HTTP request before saving the data to state.

5u.title: Components: Stoxy Form
5u.headline: Attributes
5u.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Either add  or set  dependeing on wanted to add to a colleciton in state, or deplace the state  url In some cases you might want to send the form data to the backend. For these situations you can declare the url property. If set, sends a fetch request to given url on submit.  method If url is set, specifies the HTTP method used for the request. Defaults to GET  requireok If url is set, specifies if the HTTP request is required to return a OK status before committing the object to state.

5v.title: Components: Stoxy Form
5v.headline: Usage

5w.title: Components: Stoxy Form
5w.headline: Sending the form data to a API on submit
5w.body:
In some cases we might want to send the data from the form to a backend API while we save it to our state at the
same time. This can be done by utilizing the stoxy-form's url  attribute. 
import  '@stoxy/form' ; 
  
<stoxy-form
    key="todos"
    action="add"
    url="https://my-website.app/todoadd"
    method="POST"
    requireok
    @submit=${() => {
         this.shadowRoot.querySelector('input').value = '';
    }}
>
    < input 
        type = " text"  
        name = " task"  
        placeholder = " Add todo..."  
        autocomplete = " off"  
    />  
    < input  type = " submit"   value = " Submit"   />  
</ stoxy-form >  

  
In the above case, a POST request would be made to https://my-website.app/todoadd , with the body
{ task: "Your input" } . 
The requireok  attribute means that unless we get a OK response from the backend, we won't save the
data to state either.

automatically, without any input from the developer. 
The updates are ran in a dynamic fashion, and only the content that has updated will be changed. 
With elements like Stoxy Repeat , the iterable stateobject are
compared to their old state, and sorted automatically to match the new order of the
state array. Only the items in the wrong order are moved around the DOM, and the ones that didn't change order
will be kept untouched.

7i.title: Getting started: Core functionality
7i.headline: Reactivity
7i.body:
On top of the reactivity provided by the Stoxy elements, the developer can also subscribe to the
state updates happening around their web application. 
The developer is able to set a callback function to be called with the new data set onto the state, as the
state updates. This allows for reactive programming patterns to be done by the developer even without using
Stoxy elements. 
import  { sub}  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

sub ( "shoppingcart" ,  ( )  =>  console . log ( "Shopping card updated" ) ) ; 
  

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?

7r.title: Recipes: Persisting data
7r.headline: Recipes: Persisting data
7r.body:
Persisting data means that the state persists through page reloads and even
navigation outside of the page. 
There are plenty of situtations where you might want to persist data. One example
would be persisting API data that doesn't update often, or implementing a Stale-While-Revalidate 
state management system 
Persisting data to IndexedDB isn't on by default, and needs to be opted in on a per-key basis. 
After declaring the key with persistKey  all the state of that key is persisted into the IndexedDB. 
import  {  persistKey }  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

persistKey ( "shoppingcart" ,  "userhistory" ) ;

7s.title: Recipes: Persisting data
7s.headline: Memory management
7s.body:
Persisting data onto the IndexedDB could also have a performance benefit. When persisting data, the Stoxy
system only keeps the latest 5 cache objects in memory cache, and let's the garbage collection handle older
state objects. 
This means that for an application using a large amount of state keys, it might be beneficial to persist the data
to enable the memory management benefits.

8b.headline: Offline-ready

8c.headline: DocsMotivation

8d.title: Docs
8d.headline: Simplicity
8d.body:
All of Stoxy's commands are 1-2 parameters long, and can be executed as "one-liners". 
They are however extremely extendable due to the nature of the state management system of Stoxy. Some of the Stoxy core
functions like update  and remove   even take delegates or predicates as a parameter to give the developer
more control over their state management.

8e.title: Docs
8e.headline: Ecosystem
8e.body:
Stoxy ships with a small set of Web Components, which are framework agnostic components ready for use in any project. 
The components are built to as reactive pieces of an application, updating their contents accordin to state
change without the developer having to do any work.

8f.title: Docs
8f.headline: Persistence
8f.body:
Stoxy comes shipped with persistence out of the box. There are many cases in which it is beneficial to persist the state
data through page reloads and navigation. Wether it be stale-while-revalidate patterns, or just static information fetched
from the API. 
The Persistence in Stoxy is opt-in, meaning that you control exactly what information gets persisted.

8g.title: Docs
8g.headline: Use them how you want to
8g.body:
The whole core set of Stoxy is built from smaller modules, which can be attached at will. 
This means that you can use Stoxy only for managing state, and then handle all the events through subscribers,
or you can go all in on Stoxy and deploy a whole application built with stoxy elements using barely any Javascript

8j.title: Components: Stoxy Form
8j.headline: Components: Stoxy Form
8j.body:
Stoxy Form is a web component used for handling Stoxy state without
having to write any javascript. 
On submit, the form persists the form's data to state with the given key attribute. 
If the url attribute is set, the form creates a HTTP request before saving the data to state.

8k.title: Components: Stoxy Form
8k.headline: Attributes
8k.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Either add  or set  dependeing on wanted to add to a colleciton in state, or deplace the state  url In some cases you might want to send the form data to the backend. For these situations you can declare the url property. If set, sends a fetch request to given url on submit.  method If url is set, specifies the HTTP method used for the request. Defaults to GET  requireok If url is set, specifies if the HTTP request is required to return a OK status before committing the object to state.

8l.title: Components: Stoxy Form
8l.headline: Usage

8m.title: Components: Stoxy Form
8m.headline: Sending the form data to a API on submit
8m.body:
In some cases we might want to send the data from the form to a backend API while we save it to our state at the
same time. This can be done by utilizing the stoxy-form's url  attribute. 
import  '@stoxy/form' ; 
  
<stoxy-form
    key="todos"
    action="add"
    url="https://my-website.app/todoadd"
    method="POST"
    requireok
    @submit=${() => {
         this.shadowRoot.querySelector('input').value = '';
    }}
>
    < input 
        type = " text"  
        name = " task"  
        placeholder = " Add todo..."  
        autocomplete = " off"  
    />  
    < input  type = " submit"   value = " Submit"   />  
</ stoxy-form >  

  
In the above case, a POST request would be made to https://my-website.app/todoadd , with the body
{ task: "Your input" } . 
The requireok  attribute means that unless we get a OK response from the backend, we won't save the
data to state either.

data across page reloads and navigation. The usage of IDB also means that state persisted onto it is accessible
even when the user is offline.

bi.body:
Stoxy Repeat is a web component used for iterating state content onto the web page. 
The repeat component is useful for situations where the state object is iterable
and is desired to be displayed as e.g. a list 

As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Repeat also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

cy.title: Getting started: Core functionality
cy.headline: Getting started: Core functionality
cy.body:
Stoxy is a dynamic state management system, which allows the developer to handle state across the whole
application without hassle. 
Stoxy utilizes the IndexedDB  to persist
data across page reloads and navigation. The usage of IDB also means that state persisted onto it is accessible
even when the user is offline.

cz.title: Getting started: Core functionality
cz.headline: Persistance

d0.title: Getting started: Core functionality
d0.headline: Updates
d0.body:
Stoxy elements are a perfect tool for creating reactive web experiences. When using Stoxy elements, the developer
doesn't need to worry about reacting to state changes. The elements handle their state and updates to said state
automatically, without any input from the developer. 
The updates are ran in a dynamic fashion, and only the content that has updated will be changed. 
With elements like Stoxy Repeat , the iterable stateobject are
compared to their old state, and sorted automatically to match the new order of the
state array. Only the items in the wrong order are moved around the DOM, and the ones that didn't change order
will be kept untouched.

d1.title: Getting started: Core functionality
d1.headline: Reactivity
d1.body:
On top of the reactivity provided by the Stoxy elements, the developer can also subscribe to the
state updates happening around their web application. 
The developer is able to set a callback function to be called with the new data set onto the state, as the
state updates. This allows for reactive programming patterns to be done by the developer even without using
Stoxy elements. 
import  { sub}  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

sub ( "shoppingcart" ,  ( )  =>  console . log ( "Shopping card updated" ) ) ; 
  

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?

d2.title: Getting started: Installation
d2.headline: Getting started: Installation
d2.body:
Stoxy can be installed as single packages or as a collection of all Stoxy elements and the core. 
To install the whole Stoxy project in one go, you can do so with 
npm  install  @stoxy/stoxy
  

Alternatively the packages can be installed as standalone installations

d9.title: Recipes: Persisting data
d9.headline: Recipes: Persisting data
d9.body:
Persisting data means that the state persists through page reloads and even
navigation outside of the page. 
There are plenty of situtations where you might want to persist data. One example
would be persisting API data that doesn't update often, or implementing a Stale-While-Revalidate 
state management system 
Persisting data to IndexedDB isn't on by default, and needs to be opted in on a per-key basis. 
After declaring the key with persistKey  all the state of that key is persisted into the IndexedDB. 
import  {  persistKey }  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

persistKey ( "shoppingcart" ,  "userhistory" ) ;

da.title: Recipes: Persisting data
da.headline: Memory management
da.body:
Persisting data onto the IndexedDB could also have a performance benefit. When persisting data, the Stoxy
system only keeps the latest 5 cache objects in memory cache, and let's the garbage collection handle older
state objects. 
This means that for an application using a large amount of state keys, it might be beneficial to persist the data
to enable the memory management benefits.

The reactive state management system equipped with Web Components

do.title: Stoxy
do.headline: Why Stoxy?Small
do.body: No dependencies and no need for build tools.

dp.title: Stoxy
dp.headline: Global state
dp.body: Handle state across the whole application, with immediate response from components.

dq.title: Stoxy
dq.headline: Zero Configuration
dq.body: With plug and play implementation, you're up and running in just a single line of code.

dr.title: Stoxy
dr.headline: Extensive tooling
dr.body: Stoxy ships with framework agnostic components to use with the state management system to achieve optimal results with your Web Application.

ds.title: Stoxy
ds.headline: Extendability
ds.body: Built with small and powerful functions, allowing you to extend the functionality with predicates and delegates.

dt.title: Stoxy
dt.headline: Offline-ready
dt.body: Stoxy can utilize the IndexedDB for storage, allowing you to create offline-first experiences without the hassle.

du.title: Docs
du.headline: DocsMotivation

dv.title: Docs
dv.headline: Simplicity
dv.body:
All of Stoxy's commands are 1-2 parameters long, and can be executed as "one-liners". 
They are however extremely extendable due to the nature of the state management system of Stoxy. Some of the Stoxy core
functions like update  and remove   even take delegates or predicates as a parameter to give the developer
more control over their state management.

dw.title: Docs
dw.headline: Ecosystem
dw.body:
Stoxy ships with a small set of Web Components, which are framework agnostic components ready for use in any project. 
The components are built to as reactive pieces of an application, updating their contents accordin to state
change without the developer having to do any work.

dx.title: Docs
dx.headline: Persistence
dx.body:
Stoxy comes shipped with persistence out of the box. There are many cases in which it is beneficial to persist the state
data through page reloads and navigation. Wether it be stale-while-revalidate patterns, or just static information fetched
from the API. 
The Persistence in Stoxy is opt-in, meaning that you control exactly what information gets persisted.

dy.title: Docs
dy.headline: Use them how you want to
dy.body:
The whole core set of Stoxy is built from smaller modules, which can be attached at will. 
This means that you can use Stoxy only for managing state, and then handle all the events through subscribers,
or you can go all in on Stoxy and deploy a whole application built with stoxy elements using barely any Javascript 

  
    
        
         
       

  Show Navigation

dz.title: Guides
dz.headline: Guides
dz.body:
In the guides section you can find multiple examples of utilizing Stoxy and Stoxy Elements

e1.title: Components: Stoxy Form
e1.headline: Components: Stoxy Form
e1.body:
Stoxy Form is a web component used for handling Stoxy state without
having to write any javascript. 
On submit, the form persists the form's data to state with the given key attribute. 
If the url attribute is set, the form creates a HTTP request before saving the data to state.

e2.title: Components: Stoxy Form
e2.headline: Attributes
e2.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Either add  or set  dependeing on wanted to add to a colleciton in state, or deplace the state  url In some cases you might want to send the form data to the backend. For these situations you can declare the url property. If set, sends a fetch request to given url on submit.  method If url is set, specifies the HTTP method used for the request. Defaults to GET  requireok If url is set, specifies if the HTTP request is required to return a OK status before committing the object to state.

e3.title: Components: Stoxy Form
e3.headline: Usage

e4.title: Components: Stoxy Form
e4.headline: Sending the form data to a API on submit
e4.body:
In some cases we might want to send the data from the form to a backend API while we save it to our state at the
same time. This can be done by utilizing the stoxy-form's url  attribute. 
import  '@stoxy/form' ; 
  
<stoxy-form
    key="todos"
    action="add"
    url="https://my-website.app/todoadd"
    method="POST"
    requireok
    @submit=${() => {
         this.shadowRoot.querySelector('input').value = '';
    }}
>
    < input 
        type = " text"  
        name = " task"  
        placeholder = " Add todo..."  
        autocomplete = " off"  
    />  
    < input  type = " submit"   value = " Submit"   />  
</ stoxy-form >  

  
In the above case, a POST request would be made to https://my-website.app/todoadd , with the body
{ task: "Your input" } . 
The requireok  attribute means that unless we get a OK response from the backend, we won't save the
data to state either.

fp.title: Getting started: Core functionality
fp.headline: Getting started: Core functionality
fp.body:
Stoxy is a dynamic state management system, which allows the developer to handle state across the whole
application without hassle. 
Stoxy utilizes the IndexedDB  to persist
data across page reloads and navigation. The usage of IDB also means that state persisted onto it is accessible
even when the user is offline.

fq.title: Getting started: Core functionality
fq.headline: Persistance

fr.title: Getting started: Core functionality
fr.headline: Updates
fr.body:
Stoxy elements are a perfect tool for creating reactive web experiences. When using Stoxy elements, the developer
doesn't need to worry about reacting to state changes. The elements handle their state and updates to said state
automatically, without any input from the developer. 
The updates are ran in a dynamic fashion, and only the content that has updated will be changed. 
With elements like Stoxy Repeat , the iterable stateobject are
compared to their old state, and sorted automatically to match the new order of the
state array. Only the items in the wrong order are moved around the DOM, and the ones that didn't change order
will be kept untouched.

fs.title: Getting started: Core functionality
fs.headline: Reactivity
fs.body:
On top of the reactivity provided by the Stoxy elements, the developer can also subscribe to the
state updates happening around their web application. 
The developer is able to set a callback function to be called with the new data set onto the state, as the
state updates. This allows for reactive programming patterns to be done by the developer even without using
Stoxy elements. 
import  { sub}  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

sub ( "shoppingcart" ,  ( )  =>  console . log ( "Shopping card updated" ) ) ;

g0.title: Recipes: Persisting data
g0.headline: Recipes: Persisting data
g0.body:
Persisting data means that the state persists through page reloads and even
navigation outside of the page. 
There are plenty of situtations where you might want to persist data. One example
would be persisting API data that doesn't update often, or implementing a Stale-While-Revalidate 
state management system 
Persisting data to IndexedDB isn't on by default, and needs to be opted in on a per-key basis. 
After declaring the key with persistKey  all the state of that key is persisted into the IndexedDB. 
import  {  persistKey }  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

persistKey ( "shoppingcart" ,  "userhistory" ) ;

g1.title: Recipes: Persisting data
g1.headline: Memory management
g1.body:
Persisting data onto the IndexedDB could also have a performance benefit. When persisting data, the Stoxy
system only keeps the latest 5 cache objects in memory cache, and let's the garbage collection handle older
state objects. 
This means that for an application using a large amount of state keys, it might be beneficial to persist the data
to enable the memory management benefits.

gm.title: Docs
gm.headline: Simplicity
gm.body:
All of Stoxy's commands are 1-2 parameters long, and can be executed as "one-liners". 
They are however extremely extendable due to the nature of the state management system of Stoxy. Some of the Stoxy core
functions like update  and remove   even take delegates or predicates as a parameter to give the developer
more control over their state management.

gn.title: Docs
gn.headline: Ecosystem
gn.body:
Stoxy ships with a small set of Web Components, which are framework agnostic components ready for use in any project. 
The components are built to as reactive pieces of an application, updating their contents accordin to state
change without the developer having to do any work.

go.title: Docs
go.headline: Persistence
go.body:
Stoxy comes shipped with persistence out of the box. There are many cases in which it is beneficial to persist the state
data through page reloads and navigation. Wether it be stale-while-revalidate patterns, or just static information fetched
from the API. 
The Persistence in Stoxy is opt-in, meaning that you control exactly what information gets persisted.

gp.title: Docs
gp.headline: Use them how you want to
gp.body:
The whole core set of Stoxy is built from smaller modules, which can be attached at will. 
This means that you can use Stoxy only for managing state, and then handle all the events through subscribers,
or you can go all in on Stoxy and deploy a whole application built with stoxy elements using barely any Javascript

gr.title: Components: Stoxy Form
gr.headline: Components: Stoxy Form
gr.body:
Stoxy Form is a web component used for handling Stoxy state without
having to write any javascript. 
On submit, the form persists the form's data to state with the given key attribute. 
If the url attribute is set, the form creates a HTTP request before saving the data to state.

gs.title: Components: Stoxy Form
gs.headline: Attributes
gs.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Either add  or set  dependeing on wanted to add to a colleciton in state, or deplace the state  url In some cases you might want to send the form data to the backend. For these situations you can declare the url property. If set, sends a fetch request to given url on submit.  method If url is set, specifies the HTTP method used for the request. Defaults to GET  requireok If url is set, specifies if the HTTP request is required to return a OK status before committing the object to state.

gt.title: Components: Stoxy Form
gt.headline: Usage

gu.title: Components: Stoxy Form
gu.headline: Sending the form data to a API on submit
gu.body:
In some cases we might want to send the data from the form to a backend API while we save it to our state at the
same time. This can be done by utilizing the stoxy-form's url  attribute. 
import  '@stoxy/form' ; 
  
<stoxy-form
    key="todos"
    action="add"
    url="https://my-website.app/todoadd"
    method="POST"
    requireok
    @submit=${() => {
         this.shadowRoot.querySelector('input').value = '';
    }}
>
    < input 
        type = " text"  
        name = " task"  
        placeholder = " Add todo..."  
        autocomplete = " off"  
    />  
    < input  type = " submit"   value = " Submit"   />  
</ stoxy-form >  

  
In the above case, a POST request would be made to https://my-website.app/todoadd , with the body
{ task: "Your input" } . 
The requireok  attribute means that unless we get a OK response from the backend, we won't save the
data to state either. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?

gw.headline: Components: Stoxy Object
gw.body:
Stoxy Object is a web component used for sections of content, where you want to
access multiple keys of a single state object. 
This can be useful for example when generating user profile pages. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Object also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side. 

As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Object also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

gy.body: Name Attribute   updated Triggers when the state object observed by the stoxy element is updated. Event detail contains data about the new state.

display a single state object in the DOM, for example the current item count. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy String also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

h3.body:
import  '@stoxy/stoxy-string' ; 
  
< p >  < stoxy-string >  itemcount</ stoxy-string >  </ p >

< p >  < stoxy-string >  5</ stoxy-string >  </ p >

jk.title: Components: Stoxy Form
jk.headline: Components: Stoxy Form
jk.body:
Stoxy Form is a web component used for handling Stoxy state without
having to write any javascript. 
On submit, the form persists the form's data to state with the given key attribute. 
If the url attribute is set, the form creates a HTTP request before saving the data to state.

jl.title: Components: Stoxy Form
jl.headline: Attributes
jl.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Either add  or set  dependeing on wanted to add to a colleciton in state, or deplace the state  url In some cases you might want to send the form data to the backend. For these situations you can declare the url property. If set, sends a fetch request to given url on submit.  method If url is set, specifies the HTTP method used for the request. Defaults to GET  requireok If url is set, specifies if the HTTP request is required to return a OK status before committing the object to state.

jm.title: Components: Stoxy Form
jm.headline: Usage

jn.title: Components: Stoxy Form
jn.headline: Sending the form data to a API on submit
jn.body:
In some cases we might want to send the data from the form to a backend API while we save it to our state at the
same time. This can be done by utilizing the stoxy-form's url  attribute. 
import  '@stoxy/form' ; 
  
<stoxy-form
    key="todos"
    action="add"
    url="https://my-website.app/todoadd"
    method="POST"
    requireok
    @submit=${() => {
         this.shadowRoot.querySelector('input').value = '';
    }}
>
    < input 
        type = " text"  
        name = " task"  
        placeholder = " Add todo..."  
        autocomplete = " off"  
    />  
    < input  type = " submit"   value = " Submit"   />  
</ stoxy-form >  

  
In the above case, a POST request would be made to https://my-website.app/todoadd , with the body
{ task: "Your input" } . 
The requireok  attribute means that unless we get a OK response from the backend, we won't save the
data to state either.

jo.title: Components: Stoxy Object
jo.headline: Components: Stoxy Object
jo.body:
Stoxy Object is a web component used for sections of content, where you want to
access multiple keys of a single state object. 
This can be useful for example when generating user profile pages. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Object also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side. 

As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Object also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

jp.headline: Attributes
jp.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  prefix Prefix to access wanted state object properties. Makes it possible for Stoxy to recognize plain strings to replace.

jq.title: Components: Stoxy Object
jq.headline: Events
jq.body: Name Attribute   updated Triggers when the state object observed by the stoxy element is updated. Event detail contains data about the new state.

js.title: Components: Stoxy String
js.headline: Components: Stoxy String
js.body:
Stoxy String is a web component used for situtations, where you want to
display a single state object in the DOM, for example the current item count. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy String also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side. 

As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy String also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

ju.body: Name Attribute   updated Triggers when the state object observed by the stoxy element is updated. Event detail contains data about the new state.

jv.title: Components: Stoxy String
jv.headline: Usage
jv.body:
import  '@stoxy/stoxy-string' ; 
  
< p >  < stoxy-string >  itemcount</ stoxy-string >  </ p >  
  
Say the state object of itemcount  was 5 at the moment, we would have our DOM as: 
< p >  < stoxy-string >  5</ stoxy-string >  </ p >  
  
        
          import '@rocket/launch/inline-notification/inline-notification.js';

k5.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
k5.headline: Components: Stoxy Repeat
k5.body:
Stoxy Repeat is a web component used for iterating state content onto the web page. 
The repeat component is useful for situations where the state object is iterable
and is desired to be displayed as e.g. a list 

As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Repeat also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

ka.headline: Methods: Persist Key
ka.body:
Declare a state object to be persisted through pageloads. 
Stoxy utilized IndexedDB to persist state objects. There could be two reasons you would want to persist your state objects: 

Persisted state objects are peristed through page page reloads / sessions 
Persisted state objects can be removed from cache, and only fetched when needed

l8.title: Getting started: Core functionality
l8.headline: Getting started: Core functionality
l8.body:
Stoxy is a dynamic state management system, which allows the developer to handle state across the whole
application without hassle. 
Stoxy utilizes the IndexedDB  to persist
data across page reloads and navigation. The usage of IDB also means that state persisted onto it is accessible
even when the user is offline.

l9.title: Getting started: Core functionality
l9.headline: Persistance

la.title: Getting started: Core functionality
la.headline: Updates
la.body:
Stoxy elements are a perfect tool for creating reactive web experiences. When using Stoxy elements, the developer
doesn't need to worry about reacting to state changes. The elements handle their state and updates to said state
automatically, without any input from the developer. 
The updates are ran in a dynamic fashion, and only the content that has updated will be changed. 
With elements like Stoxy Repeat , the iterable stateobject are
compared to their old state, and sorted automatically to match the new order of the
state array. Only the items in the wrong order are moved around the DOM, and the ones that didn't change order
will be kept untouched.

lb.title: Getting started: Core functionality
lb.headline: Reactivity
lb.body:
On top of the reactivity provided by the Stoxy elements, the developer can also subscribe to the
state updates happening around their web application. 
The developer is able to set a callback function to be called with the new data set onto the state, as the
state updates. This allows for reactive programming patterns to be done by the developer even without using
Stoxy elements. 
import  { sub}  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

sub ( "shoppingcart" ,  ( )  =>  console . log ( "Shopping card updated" ) ) ;

ld.title: Getting started: Installation
ld.headline: Getting started: Installation
ld.body:
Stoxy can be installed as single packages or as a collection of all Stoxy elements and the core. 
To install the whole Stoxy project in one go, you can do so with 
npm  install  @stoxy/stoxy
  

Alternatively the packages can be installed as standalone installations

lk.title: Recipes: Persisting data
lk.headline: Recipes: Persisting data
lk.body:
Persisting data means that the state persists through page reloads and even
navigation outside of the page. 
There are plenty of situtations where you might want to persist data. One example
would be persisting API data that doesn't update often, or implementing a Stale-While-Revalidate 
state management system 
Persisting data to IndexedDB isn't on by default, and needs to be opted in on a per-key basis. 
After declaring the key with persistKey  all the state of that key is persisted into the IndexedDB. 
import  {  persistKey }  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

persistKey ( "shoppingcart" ,  "userhistory" ) ;

ll.title: Recipes: Persisting data
ll.headline: Memory management
ll.body:
Persisting data onto the IndexedDB could also have a performance benefit. When persisting data, the Stoxy
system only keeps the latest 5 cache objects in memory cache, and let's the garbage collection handle older
state objects. 
This means that for an application using a large amount of state keys, it might be beneficial to persist the data
to enable the memory management benefits. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
